fully_described_observables.observable_value: /RemoteManagement/ARDAgent.app/Contents/Resources/kickstart -activate /bin/launchctl list com.apple.screensharing 2>/dev/null localonly -create /Local/Target/Users/oleq naprivs /usr/bin/dscl ' / var/db/ds local/nodes/Default' /usr/bin/defaults write /Library/Preferences/com.apple.RemoteManagement ARD_AllLocalUsers -boolean YBS /usr/bin/defaults write /Library/Preferences/com.apple.RemoteManagement ARD_AllLocalUsersPrivs -integer 1073742079 -p infected -r aGNOStIC7890 !!! -setcomputersleep Never
fully_described_observables.notes: Command to enable remote management and set root password.
fully_described_observables.text/code_section: The commands used for this are:

fully_described_observables.notes: Command to enable root user with specified password.
fully_described_observables.text/code_section: Note that although the user "root" exists in macOS, it is disabled by default. Interestingly, after a reboot, Calisto again requests user data, but this time waits for the input of the actual root password, which it previously changed itself (root: aGNOStIC7890!!!).

insufficient_observables.text/code_section: Malware for macOS is not that common, and this sample was found to contain some suspiciously familiar features.
We recently came across one such sample: a macOS backdoor that we named Calisto.
Keychain storage data
An important feature of Calisto is getting remote access to the user system.
Enables remote access to the system

fully_described_observables.notes: A remote access trojan used by various threat actors including APT10.
fully_described_observables.text/code_section: APT10 ceased its use of the Poison Ivy malware family after a 2013 FireEye report, which comprehensively detailed the malware's functionality and features...

fully_described_observables.notes: A remote access tool used by APT10 from 2014 to 2016.
fully_described_observables.text/code_section: APT10 primarily used PlugX malware from 2014 to 2016, progressively improving and deploying newer versions...

fully_described_observables.notes: A bespoke malware family used by APT10.
fully_described_observables.text/code_section: Since late 2016, we have seen the threat actor develop several bespoke malware families, such as ChChes and RedLeaves...

fully_described_observables.notes: A remote access trojan used by APT10 for long-term remote access.
fully_described_observables.text/code_section: The sustained malware, historically Poison Ivy, PlugX and now Quasar RAT, provides a more comprehensive feature set...

fully_described_observables.notes: A bespoke malware used by APT10 in targeting Japanese organizations.
fully_described_observables.text/code_section: In a separate series of operations, APT10 has been systematically targeting Japanese organisations using bespoke malware referred to in the public domain as 'ChChes'.

fully_described_observables.notes: A tactical malware used by APT10 for lightweight and disposable operations.
fully_described_observables.text/code_section: The tactical malware, historically EvilGrab, and now ChChes (and likely also RedLeaves), is designed to be lightweight and disposable...

fully_described_observables.notes: A tool used for credential theft.
fully_described_observables.text/code_section: APT10 will usually deploy credential theft tools such as mimikatz or PwDump, sometimes using DLL load order hijacking...

fully_described_observables.notes: A tool used for dumping password hashes.
fully_described_observables.text/code_section: APT10 will usually deploy credential theft tools such as mimikatz or PwDump, sometimes using DLL load order hijacking...

fully_described_observables.notes: An open-source reverse shell tool extended by APT10 to increase internal version numbers.
fully_described_observables.text/code_section: Since late 2016, we have seen the threat actor develop several bespoke malware families, such as ChChes and RedLeaves. Additionally, it has taken the open source malware, Quasar, and extended its capabilities...

insufficient_observables.text/code_section: APT10's standard compromise methodology begins with a spear phishing email sent to the target...
using DLL load order hijacking, to use against a domain controller...
the compression tools are often launched via a remote command execution script which is regularly named 't.vbs'...
Mounting the target external network share with 'net use' and subsequently using the legitimate Robocopy tool to transfer the data...
subsequently using the legitimate Robocopy tool to transfer the data...
Using the legitimate Putty Secure Copy Client (PSCP), sometimes named rundll32.exe, to transfer the data directly...
using the legitimate Putty Secure Copy Client (PSCP), sometimes named rundll32.exe, to transfer the data directly...
APT10 used either a reverse shell or RDP connection to install its malware...
APT10 used either a reverse shell or RDP connection to install its malware...
using scheduled tasks or Windows services in order to ensure the malware remains active...
use of RDP to interactively access systems in both the MSP management network and MSP customer networks...
Communication checks are usually conducted using native Windows tools such as ping.exe, net.exe and tcping.exe...
Communication checks are usually conducted using native Windows tools such as ping.exe, net.exe and tcping.exe...
Communication checks are usually conducted using native Windows tools such as ping.exe, net.exe and tcping.exe...
APT10 has been observed to exfiltrate stolen intellectual property via the MSPs, hence evading local network defenses... similar method of a supply chain attack...
APT10 achieves persistence on its targets primarily by using scheduled tasks or Windows services...

fully_described_observables.observable_value: ```openssl x509 -pubkey -in example_certificate.der -inform der | openssl pkey -pubin - outform der | openssl dgst -sha256 -binary | base64```
fully_described_observables.notes: Command to generate the hash of a DER-encoded certificate's subjectPublicKeyInfo
fully_described_observables.text/code_section:
If your certificate is DER encoded, use this command:

```
openssl x509 -pubkey -in example_certificate.der -inform der | openssl pkey -pubin -
   outform der | openssl dgst -sha256 -binary | base64
```
